While I can "export" my mail into a .pst file from Outlook, I can't seem to import this file into Thunderbird. Things look good when I select tools/import/import from outlook ... creator: janhowley54

content:
janhowley54 said
Hello, I too have just become an escapee from MS Office 365! I run on Windows 11 desktop and have MS Outlook client installed. I've just downloaded Thunderbird. While I can "export" my mail into a .pst file from Outlook, I can't seem to import this file into Thunderbird. Things look good when I select tools/import/import from outlook ... I get this error message "NO PROFILE FOUND" ? I have no clue what that message is. What profile? There is no help file within Thunderbird...

Did you run TB and add a mail account? I think the Local Folders part of the profile, where TB stores user data, isn't created until a mail account is added. Local Folders is where TB will import the Outlook data. When you run the import from Outlook, and are given a choice between 'Everything' or mail, contacts etc. separately, don't select 'Everything', as that has failed in the past.

If all else fails, the method using MailStore Home, cited above, has been successful for many users.
creator: sfhowes

content:
There are a couple hidden settings affecting the resolution at which Thunderbird displays that may have an erroneous value. You may check whether that's the case and reset them to their default values as follows.

Go to Settings > General, click Config Editor at the bottom, then repeat the following procedure with each of the following settings:

layout.css.dpi layout.css.devPixelsPerPx

1. Type the setting name (e.g. layout.css.dpi) into the search box of the Config Editor Advanced Preferences tab just opened.

2. If something has caused the setting to be changed from the default, a 'Reset' button with a counter clockwise arrow will be available to the right of the 'Edit' button for the setting. Click that button to reset the setting to the default value. If no 'Reset' button appears, the setting already has the default value.

content:
1. If you want to set the priority of the email you are composing: (In the Composition Window) Options > Priority > select the priority you want.

2. If you want to see the priority of emails in the Message List Pane, you have to use Table View instead of Cards View.

First, click "Message list display options", and then select "Table View".

Second, click "Select columns to display", and then select "Priority".

content: There is also no "exclamation point" or "down arrow" icon. Priority (when the display column has been enabled in Thunderbird) is displayed only as text: Lowest, Low, High, Highest. There is no text for Normal priority. There are no icons.

Se la configurazione prevede Sicurezza della connessione: nessuna come vedo nell'immagine, allora la porta 25 è corretta. Tuttavia sono impostazioni che sono ormai desuete da molti anni, mi pare strano che un provider le usi ancora (si tratta di impostazioni in cui la password di accesso viene inviata in chiaro, cosa che ne può compromettere la sicurezza)

Tuttavia ancora non capisco da dove venga fuori il server di Telecom Italia... Hai per caso un connessione TIM/Telecom con un modem/router? L'indirizzo 192.168.0.16 è infatti l'indirizzo di una rete locale, il che mi fa pensare che il tuo PC non sia collegato direttamente alla rete e che potrebbe esserci un problema nella configurazione della rete locale.

Per l'account in questione, puoi verificare un'altra impostazione? Tasto menu > Impostazione account > NOME_ACCOUNT Nella parte destra della finestra, a fondo pagina, come è impostata la riga Server in uscita (SMTP): ?

content:
I cannot reset a password, but can offer tips on removing the current one. That is, if the current password is removed, my hope is that you can enter a new password. Here are steps to remove current password: - click settings>privacy&security - click saved passwords and then show passwords - now, highight the rows (normally two) for the account and delete them

The removes the passwords for the account, so you should now be prompted for the password.

content:
Google uses OAuth2 authentication instead of username and password. Thunderbird keeps an OAuth2 token to authenticate when it needs to access your Google account. Changing your Google password causes this OAuth2 token to be revoked (no longer valid), much like it would cause the password to be invalid if a password was used for authentication, only the process to make the change in Thunderbird is more convoluted than a mere password change would be because you'll have to authorise Thunderbird to use your Google account again.

You may need to remove the 'OAuth' entries kept by Thunderbird for the account in Settings > Privacy & Security > Saved Passwords and/or restart Thunderbird in order for the authorisation process to start again. You'll need to have cookies and JavaScript enabled as described in the following article for that to work:

https://support.mozilla.org/kb/automatic-conversion-google-mail-accounts-oauth20
creator: DavidGG

content:
MIke Brown said
I have activated the "today" pane - but it doesn't display the calendar?

Why should it? The Today pane is just a preview to remind events of the actual day and some days or weeks in the future. content:
"If you do a search in the c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird\profiles folder, you may find abook.sqlite and history.sqlite. These are the technical filenames of the addresssbook and the collected addressbook. You can import them with tools>import>importfromafile. This sometimes happens, that thunderbird creates a new profile and some content is left behind. No, this does not happen to everyone and is likely a glitch wherein an update was interrupted by another program, such as an antivirus product."

This might help. search for "abook.sqlite". Found it in a file, C:/windows.old. look for last oldest.

content:
I don't know how to put the tag icon from the right to the left; probably it can be done with some CSS code in the userChrome.css file.

I have some code to colourize tagged messages: see screen shot below. If you're interested I can give you the CSS code
creator: Mapenzi

content: Hi, can I have that code too? Thanks Paul
creator: paul90

content:
You can use the following CSS code in a userChrome.css file (works here in TB 140) 

/* :::: Threadpane cards view tweaks :::: */ 
 #threadTree[rows="thread-card"] .card-container {    color: var(--tag-color);

} 

 #threadTree  tbody tr.selected[data-properties~="tagged"] .card-container {    background-color: var(--tag-color) !important;    color: var(--tag-contrast-color) !important;

}

If you never used userChrome.css we'll tell you the details to make it work
creator: Mapenzi

content:
Don't guess the settings - use smtp.gmail.com, 465, SSL/TLS, or 587, STARTTLS; OAuth2, email address.

Disable antivirus scanning of the profile folder (or remove the AV if it's not Windows Security), and disable VPN if in use.

Check that the affected account is sending on the correct smtp:

https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/1438310

Update to the latest 115: https://archive.mozilla.org/pub/thunderbird/releases/115.18.0/win64/

587 STARTTLS

creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I just closed Firefox and then clicked on the link in the email. It started up Firefox with a new tab for the YouTube link to run in. The ad appeared at the start like usual. So having Firefox closed gives the same result as having Firefox running when I click on the link.

Thanks for asking!

It seems like Thunderbird does something in the background that shuts off the adblocker when it starts the tab to run the YouTube video.

I noticed that when I click on another YouTube video on the side of the window an ad appears when that link begins. I clicked on a couple other videos and sometimes the appears and other times it doesn't. Is this because the user ID that created the video allows or disallows ads? I have no idea. However I can say with certainty that when I start YouTube myself in an existing tab the ads never appear. When I leave YouTube and go to a different website the adblocker still works. I changed to USAToday and it asked me to turn off my adblocker so it knows the adblocker is running.

My best guess is that Thunderbird does something that allows YouTube to ignore the adblocker when Firefox opens a new tab for YouTube. Whatever text they have in the programming that starts up Firefox or opens a new tab might have an command option that tells YouTube to ignore the adblocker. It would be interesting to see the program that Thunderbird executes when it starts up YouTube in Firefox. Is this behavior unique to Firefox or would it happen if I was using another browser as my default browser? If it's independent of the browser that's being used then it must be something that is done when calling up YouTube. If it only happens with Firefox then it's something that happens when Thunderbird calls up Firefox. This is just a guess on my part but it seems like this is a reasonable way to look at it. I'm not going to change my default browser to something else at this time because I don't want to spend time playing around with it. I might try this at a later date.

I'm not a programmer so I'd need to do some basic self educating if I want to pursue this on my own. That's why I thought I'd ask about it here and see if there's something that someone in the user community might know about this.

Thanks again for asking about this!
creator: john85259

content:
Here's an update on things. From what I can tell Thunderbird has some programming that identifies your default web browser and generates and executes some HTML code that starts up YouTube and runs the video that is defined in the URL text contained in the email. I right clicked on the URL text in an email message and saved it to a text file. The file was around 71 lines long and some of the lines had over 4,000 characters in them. I can see where it sets up the controls for starting YouTube but deciphering what's going on is above my pay grade. My guess is that the programming within Thunderbird that creates the HTML commands and runs them would need to be changed to enable an ad blocker to run when YouTube is started.

It seems unlikely that the good people at Thunderbird would want to do this and it's a 100% certainty that I can't do it myself. So it looks like the best approach for me is to copy the URL string from the email message and paste it into the web browser and leave it at that. I've tried this and it seems to work okay. Kind of a neanderthal way of doing things but sometimes the simple way is the best way.

If anyone has any suggestions feel free to share them with the rest of us. Maybe someone has written their own add-on for Thunderbird that fixes this problem that isn't in the add-ons webpage.
creator: john85259

content: all thunderbird has is your last-used password. I doubt that helps you, but you can retrieve it at - settings>privacy&security - cllick savedpasswords and then showpasswords - I doubt these are useful or they would have logged you into the account - my guess is that you may need to contact your email provider for password
creator: davidsk

content:
You cannot reset the password of your email account using a mail client such as Thunderbird because all that Thunderbird does is use the password you tell it to use.

If Thunderbird (or any other mail client) could reset your password without you needing to know what the current password is, then anyone would be able to access your account by merely knowing your email address and requesting a password reset…

It's the email provider that hosts your email account who knows the password and may allow you to change it. It's there where you have to go (and be able to authenticate or prove your identity somehow) to request a password reset.
creator: DavidGG

content: I would be interested in the outlook videos, as a PDF is not a graphic, and not such to embed. Please share, as this is not possible in Thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content:
Thanks for the quick reply, David. I'm disappointed to hear this feature isn't available in TBird, but hope it will soon be added!

If you search "how to embed a PDF in my email ?" it will turn up a number of YouTube instruction videos, for example: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7PJnd0AFH8A

There will also be a list of sites with instructions, such as: https://robots.net/tech/how-to-embed-a-pdf-in-an-email/ https://smallpdf.com/blog/embed-pdf-email-complete-guide

But none of these apply to TBird.

The only workaround I've found is to convert the PDF to a JPG, then embed the JPG in the email. But the result is not as crisp in the final, received email.
creator: pigeonsontheroof

content:
I wasted some time on the first linked video. Sounds great, My copy of the outlook that I downloaded a couple of months ago has no menus that look like those in the video and most importantly does not allow the embedding of OE objects in email bodies.

I then tried the office365 Outlook, is allowed the embedding, and on clicking send converted the object to a PNG image. So outlook sends images, not PDF files. I think that should close this. Thunderbird does not embed PDF files and neither does Outlook, despite claims by well meaning folk that have not looked at what happens to their embedded objects.

Adobe offers instructions to convert PDF files to PNG files. So you can embed all the PNG files you like in Thunderbird message bodies. https://www.adobe.com/acrobat/hub/how-to-convert-pdf-to-png.html

content: First, I respect your commitment, as I also have used Thunderbird for multiple decades. My question is why you want LDIFas the default, as users regularly use CSV format. I just do not see the problem. Thanks.
creator: davidsk

content:
David,

Sorry for the delay. Got buried in email. 100-200 incoming each day (not counting spam).

I prefer the LDIF format, where each piece of data is clearly tagged. No problems with single or double quote chars embedded in data, or with newlines. Easy to diff old and new files, easy to sort. Etc.

Also, I wrote the code that parses the LDIF file around 30 years ago, and have been using it every day since then. I'd rather not re-write that code to use CSV. Easier to just manually select the LDIF format on each export.

Sure would be nice to have a way to change the default though...

--Fred
creator: fred151
